The Related Discourses

4. The Right Undertaking

Thus have I heard:1 One time, the Buddha stayed in the kingdom of Śrāvastī at Anāthapiṇḍada Park in Jeta Grove.

At that time, the Bhagavān addressed the monks, “If someone at home or who has left home undertake wrong affairs, that is not taught by me. What is the reason for that? Someone living at home or who has left home and undertakes wrong affairs won’t be pleased with the right teaching. What are wrong affairs? They are wrong view up to wrong concentration.

“If someone at home or who has left home undertakes right affairs, that is commended by me. What is the reason for that? Someone who undertakes right affairs is pleased with the right teaching and skilled at the right teaching. What are right affairs? They are right view up to right concentration.”

At that time, Bhagavān spoke in verse:

  1. “Whether they’re at home or have left,
    Someone who undertakes wrong affairs
    Will not pleased in the end
    With the unsurpassed right teaching.
  1. Whether they’re at home or have left,
    Someone who undertakes right affairs
    Will always be pleased at heart
    With the unsurpassed right teaching.”

After the Buddha had taught this discourse, the monks who heard what the Buddha had taught rejoiced and handed it down.

Endnotes

  1. This sūtra is a close parallel with SN.45.24 Dutiyapaṭipadā, but the Pali does not include a verse summary.
Translator: Charles Patton
